body: Would you mind fixing this typo, too: https://github.com/jeyhunkarimov/kafka/blob/8acf04847fb729155ca72a48e9b29601b781d706/streams/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/streams/kstream/KStreamBuilder.java#L829
@ewencp For 0.10.2 only -- there is another PR for trunk fixing this as a side task

There is a build error. Please fix before we can do a review.
Yes, some PR changed the (test) classes related with this PR so. I will fix them.

So I found the bug. It turns out that the `new_consumer` instance variable is being modified by some tests after construction. For these tests, the JMXTool will try to collect the `assigned-partitions` metric. However, for the old consumer, this metric doesn't exist. Hence the JMXTool will not capture any output, and will be considered failed.

 I updated the patch so that the `new_consumer` check happens at the very last moment before starting the JMX tool. With the latest changes, previously failing tests pass.

One more general comment. I would be better if you would not squash your commits on every update -- this can simplify reviewing the PR. And when the PR get's merged, all commits get squashed automatically anyway.

@junrao the issue is that `clearPartitionRecords ` doesn't clear the reference to the underlying `Struct`. So, it looks like this is a regression that happened when we migrated from Scala requests to Java requests for `ProduceRequest`.

Ah. Thanks for checking. That was due to the lazy initialization of the jmx attributes introduced by my latest patch. I fixed that, and kicked off a new system test : 

http://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/711/

however, there were other 'JMXTool failed to start on time' errors as well. I am crossing my fingers and hoping that those were a one off. I still can't explain why my current changes would result in the JMX tool taking too long.
